user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl:
```c
void OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;
    int                             os_flags;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    os_flags = fcntl(impl->fd, F_GETFL);
    if (os_flags == -1)
    {
        /* No recourse if F_GETFL fails - just report the error and move on. */
        OS_DEBUG("fcntl(F_GETFL): %s\n", strerror(errno));
    }
    else
    {
        os_flags |= OS_IMPL_SOCKET_FLAGS;
        if (fcntl(impl->fd, F_SETFL, os_flags) == -1)
        {
            /* No recourse if F_SETFL fails - just report the error and move on. */
            OS_DEBUG("fcntl(F_SETFL): %s\n", strerror(errno));
        }
    }

    impl->selectable = true;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_impl_file_internal_record_t OS_impl_filehandle_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_IMPL_SOCKET_FLAGS O_NONBLOCK
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no use of compiler-specific language extensions in the provided code. Specifically:
- There are no identifiers or keywords that are compiler extensions (e.g. __attribute__, __builtin_*, typeof, __volatile__, asm, nested functions, statement-expressions ({ ... }), or compiler-specific keywords).
- The macros shown (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET and OS_DEBUG) use only standard C macro facilities; the variadic macro form (OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__)) is a standard C99 feature, not a compiler extension.
- The use of bool/true/false corresponds to standard C99's stdbool.h, not a compiler extension.
- Use of POSIX APIs and symbols (fcntl, F_GETFL, F_SETFL, O_NONBLOCK, strerror, errno) are platform/library interfaces, not language/compiler extensions required to be reported under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
- The macro expansion that takes the address of its parameter (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) using &(tok)) is valid standard C usage when the caller provides an lvalue; it is not a language extension.

Therefore there are no code fragments that, based on the supplied code and symbol definitions, should be flagged for investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
